elements.content: Tunable structures and magnetocaloric effect (MCE) of seven MOFs with [Gdn] as nodes are explored. The [Gdn] node is realized from mononuclear [Gd] to binuclear paddle-wheel [Gd2], tetranuclear tetrahedral [Gd4], and pentanuclear trigonal bipyramidal [Gd5]. Meanwhile, the magnetic entropy changes from 19.4 to 46.0 J·kg–1·K–1. The results reveal that the effect of magnetic density on MCE plays a dominant role for Gd3+-based compounds, and high spin ground state of Mn2+ (S = 5/2) is more favorable to achieve high MCE than that with Zn2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ (Co2+, S = 3/2; Ni2+, S = 1). To our knowledge, it is the first report that MCE is controlled by various clusters as nodes in MOFs.

The results reveal that the effect of magnetic density on MCE plays a dominant role for Gd3+-based compounds, and high spin ground state of Mn2+ (S = 5/2) is more favorable to achieve high MCE than that with Zn2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ (Co2+, S = 3/2; Ni2+, S = 1). To our knowledge, it is the first report that MCE is controlled by various clusters as nodes in MOFs.

elements.content: Explosive increase in design and construction of metal organic frameworks (MOF) have been caught over the past years driven by their appealing crystallography and promising application in adsorption, magnetism, luminescence, catalysis, etc. As a unique type, MOFs containing clusters (3d or 4f or 3d/4f) as nodes, also known as the secondary building units (SBU), are particularly attractive, which usually endow MOFs thermal stability, permanent porosity, and robust framework. Many classic SBUs configurations in MOFs can be observed such as binuclear paddle-wheel, trinuclear triangle, tetranuclear tetrahedron, and hexanuclear octahedron. However, most of these SBUs in MOFs are based on 3d clusters. Comparatively, assembling MOFs based on 4f clusters as SBUs is rarely reported and is extremely difficult due to the variable and high coordination numbers as well as low stereochemical preferences of lanthanide ions. It is reported that few records are elaborated on exploring the modulation of SBUs in MOFs by employing the same ligand. Additionally, it is a great challenge to construct MOFs by 4f clusters and 3d ions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Explosive increase in design and construction of metal organic frameworks (MOF) have been caught over the past years driven by their appealing crystallography and promising application in adsorption, magnetism, luminescence, catalysis, etc. As a unique type, MOFs containing clusters (3d or 4f or 3d/4f) as nodes, also known as the secondary building units (SBU), are particularly attractive, which usually endow MOFs thermal stability, permanent porosity, and robust framework. Many classic SBUs configurations in MOFs can be observed such as binuclear paddle-wheel, trinuclear triangle, tetranuclear tetrahedron, and hexanuclear octahedron. However, most of these SBUs in MOFs are based on 3d clusters. Comparatively, assembling MOFs based on 4f clusters as SBUs is rarely reported and is extremely difficult due to the variable and high coordination numbers as well as low stereochemical preferences of lanthanide ions. It is reported that few records are elaborated on exploring the modulation of SBUs in MOFs by employing the same ligand. Additionally, it is a great challenge to construct MOFs by 4f clusters and 3d ions.

elements.content: On the other hand, molecule-based magnetic cryocooling materials are rapidly attracting intense interest recently, owing to their environmentally friendly, energy-efficient superiority, and high magnetocaloric effect (MCE). One of the important judging parameters for MCE is magnetic entropy change (−ΔS m), which is influenced by many factors. The studies indicate large spin ground state S, negligible magnetic anisotropy, high spin degeneracy or low lying spin ground state, and large magnetic density are favorable to obtain large −ΔS m. Consequently, many high-nuclear discrete clusters (covering Gd3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Cr3+) were extensively studied for their MCE, especially for Gd3+ and Mn2+ clusters, mainly attributing to their large spin ground state S (S = 7/2 for Gd3+ and S = 5/2 for Mn2+). More recently, molecule-based magnetic cryocooling materials tend to explore MOFs based on clusters as nodes because of their inherent advantages, which were well confirmed by our previous studies. First, clusters-based MOFs possess high magnetic density as that in discrete clusters. Second, adjacent clusters in MOFs share each bridging ligand among them, which can enhance the systematic magnetic density, resulting in a large MCE. Third, it is noteworthy that most clusters include the bridging linker OH– or O2–, and the number and coordination configuration of them can be changed by pH value, temperature, solvent, and other experimental factors, leading to various SBUs and alterable MCE. Fourth, MOFs usually present higher thermal and solvent stability than discrete clusters, which will provide a solid foundation for future application. Therefore, it is necessary to study the MCE of clusters-based MOFs. Up to date, although several magnetic cryocooling materials based on MOFs containing clusters as nodes were studied, the controlled MCE by various clusters as nodes in MOFs has not been reported.

elements.content: In pursuit of the controlled MCE, seven three-dimensional (3D) MOFs {[GdM­(L)2(H2O)3(HCOO)]·2H2O}n (M = Mn (1); M = Zn (1a)), {[Gd2Mn2(L)4.5(NO3)­(H2O)4]·2H2O}n (2); {[Gd4Mn­(L)3(H2O)3(μ3-OH)4(HCOO)1.5]­(NO3)2.5·6H2O}n (3); {[Gd5Mn­(L)3(H2O)10(μ3-OH)6]­(NO3)5·13H2O}n (4); {[Gd5Co­(L)3(H2O)10(μ3-OH)6]­(NO3)5·13H2O}n (4a); {[Gd5Ni­(L)3(H2O)10(μ3-OH)6]­(NO3)5·12H2O}n (4b) based on the H2L ligand are prepared (H2L = 2,2′-dipyridine-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (Scheme S1 in Supporting Information (SI))) by changing the pH, temperature, and solvent in this contribution. All of them are characteristic of various [Gdn] SBUs. Interestingly, the SBU changes from the mononuclear [Gd] in 1 and 1a to the binuclear paddle-wheel [Gd2] in 2, tetranuclear tetrahedral [Gd4] in 3, and pentanuclear trigonal bipyramidal [Gd5] in 4, 4a, and 4b, shown in . The MCE of these seven MOFs are well studied. From 1 to 4, the −ΔS m is in the range of 31.7 to 46.0 J·kg–1·K–1, which reveals that large magnetic density is beneficial to produce large −ΔS m. The −ΔS m of 4, 4a, and 4b is 38.3, 34.7, and 34.1 J·kg–1·K–1, respectively, which uncovers that high spin ground state of Mn2+ (S = 5/2) is more favorable to achieve high −ΔS m than that with Co2+ or Ni2+ (S = 3/2 for Co2+ and S = 1 for Ni2+).

Experimental Section

Preparation All of chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligand H2L was purchased from Jinan Camolai Trading Company. The concentration of the liquid Mn(NO3)2 is 50%.

elements.content: H2L (0.1 mmol, 0.0244 g), 0.05 mmol MCl2·6H2O (MnCl2·6H2O, 0.0099 g; ZnCl2·6H2O, 0.0122 g), 0.15 mmol Gd­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0674 g), 2 mL of distilled water, and 6 mL of DMF (N,N′-dimethylformamide) were sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless vessel (25 mL) and heated at 145 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. The vessel was then cooled slowly down to room temperature at 2 °C/h. Prismatic crystals were obtained. The yield was 18% for 1 and 65% for 1a (based on MCl2·6H2O). Elemental Anal. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compounds 1 and 1a are isostructural, crystallizing in the monoclinic system with space group C2/c. Each asymmetric unit contains one Gd3+, one M2+, two L2–, three coordinated water molecules, one formate, and two free water molecules (a). Nine-coordinated Gd3+ with distorted tricapped trigonal prism geometry is completed by six bidentate-chelating carboxylic oxygen atoms, one monodentate-coordinated carboxylic oxygen atom, one monodentate-coordinated formate oxygen atom, and one water molecule. HCOO– may arise from the decomposition of DMF, supported by the previous article. In addition, high temperature and pressure and the catalysis of MII ions also promote the hydrolyzation of DMF. Each Gd3+ is isolated, and the distance between the nearest two Gd3+ is 11.1840(6) Å in 1 and 11.1338(6) Å in 1a. Six-coordinated environment of M2+ consists of four nitrogen atoms from two L2– and two water molecules, displaying distorted octahedron geometry. L2– connects the Gd3+ and M2+ into a 3D framework, which shows a square pore along the [101] direction (Figure S1). Two sets of the independent 3D frameworks interpenetrate each other, as shown in b. The Gd–O bond lengths fall into the range of 2.337(4)–2.694(4) Å in 1 and that of 2.332(4)–2.697(4) Å in 1a. The closest distances in Gd3+···Mn2+ and Mn2+···Mn2+ in 1 are 9.2845(10) Å and 11.3345(16) Å, respectively. Gd3+ and [M­(L)3] are considered as nodes, respectively, and the framework can be simplified as a 3,4-connected tfa topology with 2-fold interpenetration (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compounds 1 and 1a are isostructural, crystallizing in the monoclinic system with space group C2/c. Each asymmetric unit contains one Gd3+, one M2+, two L2-, three coordinated water molecules, one formate, and two free water molecules (a). Nine-coordinated Gd3+ with distorted tricapped trigonal prism geometry is completed by six bidentate-chelating carboxylic oxygen atoms, one monodentate-coordinated carboxylic oxygen atom, one monodentate-coordinated formate oxygen atom, and one water molecule. HCOO- may arise from the decomposition of DMF, supported by the previous article. In addition, high temperature and pressure and the catalysis of MII ions also promote the hydrolyzation of DMF. Each Gd3+ is isolated, and the distance between the nearest two Gd3+ is 11.1840(6) Å in 1 and 11.1338(6) Å in 1a. Six-coordinated environment of M2+ consists of four nitrogen atoms from two L2- and two water molecules, displaying distorted octahedron geometry. L2- connects the Gd3+ and M2+ into a 3D framework, which shows a square pore along the [101] direction (Figure S1). Two sets of the independent 3D frameworks interpenetrate each other, as shown in b. The Gd-O bond lengths fall into the range of 2.337(4)-2.694(4) Å in 1 and that of 2.332(4)-2.697(4) Å in 1a. The closest distances in Gd3+⋅⋅⋅Mn2+ and Mn2+⋅⋅⋅Mn2+ in 1 are 9.2845(10) Å and 11.3345(16) Å, respectively. Gd3+ and [M(L)3] are considered as nodes, respectively, and the framework can be simplified as a 3,4-connected tfa topology with 2-fold interpenetration (Figure S2).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P-1. Each asymmetric unit contains one Gd3+, one Mn2+, two and quarter L2–, half NO3 –, two coordinated water molecules, and one free water molecules (a). Gd3+ is nine-coordinated with a distorted tricapped trigonal prism geometry, completed by five μ-1,3 bridging carboxylic oxygen atoms, one monodentate-coordinated carboxylic oxygen atoms, two oxygen atoms from NO3 –, and two water molecules. Interestingly, two oxygen atoms (O6 and O16) in NO3 – and two monodentate-coordinated carboxylic oxygen atoms are disordered and occupy the same location. Two Gd3+ is linked by μ-1,3 bridging carboxylic oxygen atoms into a paddel-wheel [Gd2] and the distance between the two Gd3+ is 4.4028(4) Å. Six-coordinated environment of Mn2+ consists of four nitrogen atoms from two L2– and two water molecules, which exhibits a distorted octahedron geometry. The ligand L2– presents two coordination modes, one of which is that the nitrogen is noncoordinated. The Gd–O bond lengths fall into the range of 2.320(3)–2.586(8) Å. The closest distances in Gd3+···Mn2+ and Mn2+···Mn2+ are 5.8181(7) Å and 7.9718(10) Å. L2– connects the Gd3+ and Mn2+ into a 3D framework, shown in b. [Gd2] unit and [M­(L)2] are considered as nodes, and the 3D framework can be simplified a 4,8-connected MOF with Schlafli symbol of {42·6}2{43·63}2{46·614·86·102} (Figure S3, SI).

Six-coordinated environment of Mn2+ consists of four nitrogen atoms from two L2- and two water molecules, which exhibits a distorted octahedron geometry. The ligand L2- presents two coordination modes, one of which is that the nitrogen is noncoordinated. The Gd-O bond lengths fall into the range of 2.320(3)-2.586(8) Å. The closest distances in Gd3+⋅⋅⋅Mn2+ and Mn2+⋅⋅⋅Mn2+ are 5.8181(7) Å and 7.9718(10) Å. L2- connects the Gd3+ and Mn2+ into a 3D framework, shown in b. [Gd2] unit and [M(L)2] are considered as nodes, and the 3D framework can be simplified a 4,8-connected MOF with Schlafli symbol of {42⋅6}2{43⋅63}2{46⋅614⋅86⋅102} (Figure S3, SI).

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the cubic system with space group I213. It is composed of [Gd4Mn­(L)3(H2O)3(μ3-OH)4(HCOO)3]2.5+, two and half NO3 –, and six free water molecules. Gd3+ displays two coordination configurations. Gd1 is eight coordinated with a dicapped trigonal prism geometry, surrounded by three μ3-OH, two μ-1,3 bridging carboxylic oxygen atoms, one μ-1,3 bridging formate ion, and one coordinated water molecule. The generation of formate ion is similar to the compounds 1. Six-coordinated Gd2 is completed by three μ3-OH and three μ-1,3 bridging carboxylic oxygen atoms. Gd1 and Gd2 are linked by the OH– group into a distorted cubane [Gd4O4] cluster, shown in a. Four Gd3+ ions in [Gd4O4] cluster displays a trigonal pyramid, in which Gd2 is locate on a 3-fold axis and three Gd1 occupy the plane. The distances of Gd1···Gd2 and Gd1···Gd1 in [Gd4O4] cluster are 3.8671(19) Å and 3.7830(16) Å. Formate ions bridge the [Gd4O4] cluster into a 3D framework with two kinds unusual helix channels A and B (Figure S4, SI). Channel A is L-helix and B is R-helix, which exhibit the same helix pitch 20.7 Å but different pore diameter 10.4 Å for A and 5.0 Å for B. Each [Gd4O4] cluster links other three [Gd4O4] clusters by L2–. The Gd–O bond lengths fall into the range of 2.285(17)–2.464(11) Å. Each Mn2+ is coordinated by six nitrogen atoms of three L2– with a distorted octahedral geometry, which connects six [Gd4O4] clusters by L2–. Finally, [Gd4O4] clusters, formate, Mn2+, and the L2– result in a 3D cationic framework, shown in b. The counteranion is NO3 –, confirmed by the residual electrons. [Gd4O4] and [M­(L)3] are considered as nodes, and formate is considered as line, respectively, and the framework can be simplified into a 6,9-connected sqc topological structure as shown in Figure S5, SI.

elements.content: Compounds 4, 4a, and 4b are isomorphous, only with different transitional metals, counter-anions, and free water molecules (Mn2+ in 4, Co2+ in 4a, and Ni2+ in 4b). All of them contain the [Gd5(COO)6(H2O)10(OH)6]3+ cluster node. Representatively, only the structure of 4 will be discussed in detail. 4 crystallizes in the hexagonal system with space group P3121. It is a 3D cationic MOF, composed of [Gd5Mn­(L)3(H2O)10(OH)6]5+, four free NO3 –, half free CO3 2–, and free water molecules. As shown in a, six μ3-OH bridge five Gd3+ into a pentanuclear cluster [Gd5O6], which is encapsulated by six carboxyl groups of three L2–. [Gd5O6] cluster shows the infrequent distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. Each pentanuclear cluster contains three crystallographically independent Gd3+, in which Gd2 and Gd3 are located at the equatorial plane, and Gd1 occupies the apical position. The distance of Gd1···Gd2, Gd1···Gd3, Gd2···Gd2, and Gd2···Gd3 in [Gd5O6] cluster is 3.8273 (4) Å, 3.9014(3) Å, 3.8948(4) Å, and 3.7960(5) Å. Each Gd3+ is eight-coordinated, which consist of three oxygen atoms of three μ3-OH, three carboxylic oxygen atoms of L2–, and two coordinated water molecules (a). Gd1 displays the dicapped trigonal prism coordination geometry, both Gd2 and Gd3 exhibit a square antiprism geometry. The Gd–O bond lengths fall into the range of 2.311(4)–2.479(5) Å. Each [Gd5O6] cluster connects adjacent six [Gd5O6] clusters by L2–. Mn2+ is six-coordinated with six nitrogen atoms of three L2–, displaying a distorted octahedral geometry. L2– connects the [Gd5O6] clusters and Zn2+ into a porous 3D framework, shown in b. Free water molecules and counter-anions NO3 – locate in the channels. [Gd5O6] and [Mn­(L)3] are considered as nodes, respectively, and the framework can be simplified into a 6,6-connected topological structure with Schlafli symbol of {411·64}­{46·69}, shown in Figure S6, SI.

elements.content: Compounds 1–4 contain the same metal ions Gd3+ and Mn2+, while the structures present endless variety and change, shown in . By controlling temperature, solvents, and pH value, the SBU of Gd3+ is mononuclear [Gd] in 1, binuclear paddle-wheel [Gd2] in 2, tetranuclear tetrahedral [Gd4] in 3, and pentanuclear trigonal bipyramidal [Gd5] in 4. For compounds 1 and 3, the solvent DMF is decomposed into the formate ions, which are coordinated to the Gd3+. However, only one oxygen atom of formate ions is coordinated in 1, and the other one is uncoordinated, resulting in a 2-fold interpenetration neutral MOF. For compound 3, the two oxygen atoms of formate ions are all coordinated, leading to a 3D porous cationic MOF. Under the same conditions except for the addition of TEA, binuclear paddle-wheel [Gd2] in 2 and pentanuclear trigonal bipyramidal [Gd5] in 4 were obtained. The results indicate high pH is favorable of construction multinuclear cluster.

elements.content: The compounds 1–4 are stable in air, supported by their stimulated and experimental XRD patterns (Figure S7, SI). Meanwhile, after samples are immersed in the H2O for 48 h respectively, the corresponding experimental XRD patterns are in conformity with the simulated from the single crystal data, showing the excellent stability of them.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction Analyses (PXRD), Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA), and Solid-state Circular Dichroism (CD) Spectra

The compounds 1-4 are stable in air, supported by their stimulated and experimental XRD patterns (Figure S7, SI). Meanwhile, after samples are immersed in the H2O for 48 h respectively, the corresponding experimental XRD patterns are in conformity with the simulated from the single crystal data, showing the excellent stability of them.

elements.content: To investigate the thermal stabilities and further confirm the free water molecules, thermogravimetric analysis were conducted on compounds 1–4, 1a, 4a, and 4b, shown in Figure S8, SI. Both of them display good thermal stability. For compound 1 and 1a, the weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C is 10.63% for 1 and 11.02% for 1a, corresponding to the loss of three coordinated and two free water molecules, being identical with the calculated: 10.82% for 1 and 10.69% for 1a. For compound 2, the weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C is 6.25%, corresponding to the loss of four coordinated and two free water molecules, being identical with the calculated: 6.41%. For compound 3, the weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C is 9.06%, corresponding to the loss of three coordinated and six free water molecules, being identical with the calculated: 8.69%. For compounds 4, 4a, and 4b, the weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C is 17.55% for 4, 17.53% for 4a, 16.62% for 4b, corresponding to the loss of coordinated and free water molecules, being identical with the calculated: 17.29% for 4, 17.26% for 4a, 16.64% for 4b. Obviously, compounds 3, 4, 4a, and 4b are still stable at 350 °C, which display higher thermal stability than compounds 1, 2, and 1a. As mentioned in the introduction, such result confirms MOFs based on clusters as nodes usually present excellent thermal stability.

elements.content: The compounds 3 and 4 crystallize in the space group I213 and P3121, respectively, which are chiral. Thus the solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra were measured on their single crystals from different batches, using pressed KBr pellets. The results of all solid-state CD measurements did not exhibit Cotton effect (Figure S9, SI). In addition, the flack parameter of 3, 4, 4a, and 4b is 0.00(10), 0.00(3), 0.00(2), and 0.52(2) su, respectively. It is possible that the absence of significant CD signals in them is due to racemic mixtures of different handedness in one single crystal.

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1–4, 1a, 4a, and 4b were carried out in the range of 2–300 K at 1000 Oe (Figure S10, SI). The value of χM T at room temperature is 12.14 (1), 7.80 (1a), 24.02 (2), 35.80 (3), 43.83 (4), 42.85 (4a), and 43.16 (4b) cm3·K·mol–1, respectively. Except for compound 4a, the χM T value is close to the theoretical value of 12.26 (1), 7.88 (1a), 24.51 (2), 35.89 (3), 43.78 (4), and 43.40 (4b) cm3·K·mol–1 for the unit of one (1 and 1a), two (2), four (3), five isolated Gd3+ (4 and 4b), and one isolated M2+ (Gd3+, S = 7/2, g = 2; Mn2+, S = 5/2, g = 2; Ni2+, S = 1, g = 2). For compound 4a, the χM T value is larger than the theoretical value of 41.28 cm3·K·mol–1 for the unit of five isolated Gd3+ and one isolated Co2+ (Co2+, S = 3/2, g = 2), which may be attributed to the strong spin–orbit coupling of Co2+. With lowering temperature, the χM T value of 1a, 2–4, 4a, and 4b decrease slowly in the range of 300–50 K. On further cooling, the χM T value sharply decreases to the minimum value at 2 K. The χM T value of 1 increases slowly in the range of 300–50 K, which sharply decreases to the minimum value at 2 K with further cooling temperature. This behavior may demonstrate antiferromagnetic interactions in 2–4, 1a, and 4b and weak ferromagnetic interaction in 1. For 4a, thermal depopulation of stark sublevels for Co2+ always result in the χM T value decrease with cooling temperature, which will cover the intrinsic magnetic behavior. Thus, the magnetic interaction in compound 4a can not be judged by the χM T value changes. The curves of 1/χM vs T obey the Curie–Weiss law in equation /χM = T – θ/C with C = 12.20 cm3·K·mol–1, θ = 0.78 K for 1; C = 7.81 cm3·K·mol–1, θ = −1.18 K for 1a; C = 24.00 cm3·K·mol–1, θ = −0.80 K for 2; C = 35.79 cm3·K·mol–1, θ = −2.39 K for 3; C = 43.81 cm3·K·mol–1, θ = −1.49 K for 4; C = 42.83 cm3·K·mol–1, θ = −2.09 K for 4a; C = 43.50 cm3·K·mol–1, θ = −2.52 K for 4b (Figure S11, SI). The positive θ of 1 further uncover the ferromagnetic interaction in 1, and the negative θ supports the antiferromagnetic interaction in compound 1a and 3–4b.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1-4, 1a, 4a, and 4b were carried out in the range of 2-300 K at 1000 Oe (Figure S10, SI). Except for compound 4a, the χM T value is close to the theoretical value of 12.26 (1), 7.88 (1a), 24.51 (2), 35.89 (3), 43.78 (4), and 43.40 (4b) cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 for the unit of one (1 and 1a), two (2), four (3), five isolated Gd3+ (4 and 4b), and one isolated M2+ (Gd3+, S = 7/2, g = 2; Mn2+, S = 5/2, g = 2; Ni2+, S = 1, g = 2). For compound 4a, the χM T value is larger than the theoretical value of 41.28 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 for the unit of five isolated Gd3+ and one isolated Co2+ (Co2+, S = 3/2, g = 2), which may be attributed to the strong spin-orbit coupling of Co2+. With lowering temperature, the χM T value of 1a, 2-4, 4a, and 4b decrease slowly in the range of 300-50 K. On further cooling, the χM T value sharply decreases to the minimum value at 2 K. The χM T value of 1 increases slowly in the range of 300-50 K, which sharply decreases to the minimum value at 2 K with further cooling temperature. This behavior may demonstrate antiferromagnetic interactions in 2-4, 1a, and 4b and weak ferromagnetic interaction in 1. For 4a, thermal depopulation of stark sublevels for Co2+ always result in the χM T value decrease with cooling temperature, which will cover the intrinsic magnetic behavior. Thus, the magnetic interaction in compound 4a can not be judged by the χM T value changes. The curves of 1/χM vs T obey the Curie-Weiss law in equation /χM = T - θ/C with C = 12.20 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, θ = 0.78 K for 1; C = 7.81 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, θ = -1.18 K for 1a; C = 24.00 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, θ = -0.80 K for 2; C = 35.79 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, θ = -2.39 K for 3; C = 43.81 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, θ = -1.49 K for 4; C = 42.83 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, θ = -2.09 K for 4a; C = 43.50 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, θ = -2.52 K for 4b (Figure S11, SI). elements.content: According to the previous work, cluster-based MOFs are favorable to be considered as magnetic refrigeration materials, especially for Gd3+. To explore the MCE of 1–4, 1a, 4a, and 4b, magnetization measurements of them were also performed at 2–10 K in the range of 0–7 T. M vs H plots show a steady increase with increasing filed, shown in .

elements.content: For 1, M reaches 11.81 Nβ at 2 K and 7 T, approaching the saturation value of 12 Nβ for one Gd3+ and one Mn2+ (Mn2+, S = 5/2). For 1a, M reaches 6.95 Nβ at 2 K and 7 T, approaching the saturation value of 7 Nβ for one Gd3+ (S = 7/2). For 2, M reaches 23.80 Nβ at 2 K and 7 T, approaching the saturation value of 24 Nβ for two Gd3+ and two Mn2+ (Mn2+, S = 5/2). For 3, M reaches 32.96 Nβ at 2 K and 7 T, approaching the saturation value of 33 Nβ for four Gd3+ and one Mn2+. For 4, 4a, and 4b, M reaches 39.55 (4), 36.12 (4a), and 35.82 (4b) Nβ at 2 K and 7 T, approaching the saturation value of 40 (4), 36.5 (4a), and 36 (4b) Nβ for five Gd3+ and one M2+ (Co2+, S = 3/2; Ni2+, S = 1). The MCEs of 1, 1a, 2–4, 4a, and 4b were investigated according to their M vs H data under 2–10 K at 0–7 T. As MCE can be described by the Maxwell equation −ΔS m(T) = ∫[∂M(T,H)/∂T]H dH, the maximum value of −ΔS m is 35.5 J·kg1–·K–1 for 1 at 2.5 K for ΔH =H = 7 T; 19.4 J·kg1–·K–1 for 1a at 2 K for ΔH = 7 T; 31.7 J·kg1–·K–1 for 2 at 2 K for ΔH = 7 T; 46.0 J·kg1–·K–1 for 3 at 2 K for ΔH = 7 T; 38.3 J·kg1–·K–1 for 4 at 3 K for ΔH = 7 T; 34.7 J·kg1–·K–1 for 4a at 2.5 K for ΔH = 7 T; 34.1 J·kg1–·K–1 for 4b at 2 K for ΔH = 7 T (). All of them are smaller than the expected value of uncorrelated Gd3+ (S = 7/2) and M2+ in each units, according to the equation −ΔS m = nR ln­(2S + 1) = 3.87R (1), 2.08R (1a), 7.74R (2), 10.11R (3), 12.19R (4), 11.78R (4a), and 11.50R (4b), which corresponds to 38.3 (1), 21.1 (1a), 38.2 (2), 46.7 (4), 42.2 (4a), 40.8 (4b), and 39.8 (4c) J·kg1–·K–1, respectively. The deviation from the expected value may be ascribed to the antiferromagnetic interactions in 1a, 2–4 and magnetic anisotropy in 4a and 4b. Among the reported [Gd-M] molecule-based magnetic cryocooling materials, most of them are isolated clusters. 3D [Gd-M] compounds in this work display good stability and large −ΔS m values compared with the isolated clusters ().

Importantly, magnetic entropy change −ΔS m in this work can be tunable. The maximum value of −ΔS m in 1–4 is larger than most of reported [Gd-Mn] compounds, and the −ΔS m in 3 is just behind the biggest [Mn3Gd2] MOF with the value of 50.1 J·kg1–·K–1. The maximum value of −ΔS m of 4a and 4b are lower than the high-nuclear clusters [Co10Gd42], [Ni10Gd42], and [Ni12Gd36] with the value of 41.26, 38.2, and 36.3 J·kg1–·K–1, respectively. The all results can be explained as follows. For the isostructural compounds 1 and 1a, the different metal ions result in the difference of −ΔS m value, which confirms high-spin ground state of Mn2+ is favorable to achieve magnetic refrigeration materials. For the different structures of 1–4, which contain the same metal ions, the −ΔS m values change from 31.7 to 46.0 J·kg–1·K–1. Such a result may be mainly ascribed to the different magnetic density in them. The magnetic density of 3d–4f compounds with negligible magnetic interactions could be roughly obtained based on the equation (nS Gd 3+ + nS M 2+) × 1000/M r (n represents the number of Gd3+ ions or the number of Mn2+ ions in the molecule; M r is the molecular weight). From compounds 1–4, the magnetic densities are 7.21, 7.12, 8.67, and 8.86, respectively. The results indicate the larger of the magnetic density, the larger of the −ΔS m. For the isostructures of 4, 4a, 4b, and the reported [Gd5–Zn] (4c) in our previous work, the S value and magnetic anisotropy all affect the value of −ΔS m. By comparison of them, it turns out that large S also lead to large −ΔS m. The results shows that construction of high magnetic density MOFs based on Gd3+ and Mn2+ is favorable for molecule magnetic refrigeration materials, shown in .

elements.content: In summary, seven 3D MOFs containing various [Gdn] as nodes were synthesized and magnetically characterized. All of them present excellent chemical and thermal stabilities. Noteworthily, structures and MCE investigations on them were controlled elaborately by controlling pH, temperature, and solvent. The [Gdn] nodes display endless variety and change, and the −ΔS m changes from 19.4 to 46.0 J·kg–1·K–1. The results confirm that high-spin the ground state of Mn2+ and Gd3+ are favorable to achieve high MCE, and the effect of magnetic density on MCE plays a dominant role for Gd3+-based compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, seven 3D MOFs containing various [Gdn] as nodes were synthesized and magnetically characterized. All of them present excellent chemical and thermal stabilities. Noteworthily, structures and MCE investigations on them were controlled elaborately by controlling pH, temperature, and solvent. The [Gdn] nodes display endless variety and change, and the -ΔS m changes from 19.4 to 46.0 J⋅kg-1⋅K-1. The results confirm that high-spin the ground state of Mn2+ and Gd3+ are favorable to achieve high MCE, and the effect of magnetic density on MCE plays a dominant role for Gd3+-based compounds.

H2L (0.1 mmol, 0.0244 g), 0.05 mmol MCl2·6H2O (MnCl2·6H2O, 0.0099 g; ZnCl2·6H2O, 0.0122 g), 0.15 mmol Gd­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0674 g), 2 mL of distilled water, and 6 mL of DMF (N,N′-dimethylformamide) were sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless vessel (25 mL) and heated at 145 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. The vessel was then cooled slowly down to room temperature at 2 °C/h. Prismatic crystals were obtained. The yield was 18% for 1 and 65% for 1a (based on MCl2·6H2O). Elemental Anal. (%) Compound 1 Calcd: C, 36.10. H, 2.79; N: 6.74. Found: C, 36.32; H, 2.99; N: 6.93. Compound 1a Calcd: C, 35.66. H, 2.75; N: 6.65. Found: C, 35.82; H, 2.69; N: 6.51.

{[Gd<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(L)<sub>4.5</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>n</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

H2L (0.1 mmol, 0.0244 g), 0.15 mL of Mn­(NO3)2, 0.2 mmol Gd­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0674 g), 4 mL of distilled water, and 4 mL of absolute ethanol were sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless vessel (25 mL) and heated at 130 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. The vessel was then cooled slowly down to room temperature at 3 °C/h. Yellow block crystals were obtained. The yield was 68% (based on H2L). Elemental Anal. (%) Calcd: C, 38.51. H, 2.33; N: 8.32. Found: C, 38.29; H, 2.54; N: 8.09.

{[Gd<sub>4</sub>Mn­(L)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>(μ<sub>3</sub>-OH)<sub>4</sub>(HCOO)<sub>1.5</sub>]·(NO3)<sub>2.5</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>n</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

H2L (0.1 mmol, 0.0244 g), 0.1 mmol MnCl2·6H2O (0.0198 g), 0.15 mmol Gd­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0674 g), 4 mL of distilled water, and 4 mL of DMF were sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless vessel (25 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 96 h under autogenous pressure. The vessel was then cooled slowly down to room temperature at 3 °C/h. Yellow-green polyhedral crystals were obtained. The yield was 32% (based on H2L). Elemental anal (%). Calcd: C, 24.17. H, 2.24; N: 6.39. Found: C, 24.01; H, 2.09; N: 6.75.

{[Gd<sub>5</sub>Mn­(L)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>10</sub>(μ<sub>3</sub>-OH)<sub>6</sub>]­(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>5</sub>·13H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>n</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

H2L (0.1 mmol, 0.0244 g), 0.15 mL of Mn­(NO3)2, 0.15 mmol Gd­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0674 g), 50 μL of triethylamine (TEA), 4 mL of distilled water, and 4 mL of absolute ethanol were sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless vessel (25 mL) and heated at 130 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. The vessel was then cooled slowly down to room temperature at 3 °C/h. Yellow polyhedral crystals were obtained. The yield was 49% (based on H2L). Elemental Anal. (%) Calcd: C, 18.06. cln_elements.content:
Tunable structures and magnetocaloric effect (MCE) of seven MOFs with [Gdn] as nodes are explored. The [Gdn] node is realized from mononuclear [Gd] to binuclear paddle-wheel [Gd2], tetranuclear tetrahedral [Gd4], and pentanuclear trigonal bipyramidal [Gd5]. Meanwhile, the magnetic entropy changes from 19.4 to 46.0 J·kg–1·K–1. The results reveal that the effect of magnetic density on MCE plays a dominant role for Gd3+-based compounds, and high spin ground state of Mn2+ (S = 5/2) is more favorable to achieve high MCE than that with Zn2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ (Co2+, S = 3/2; Ni2+, S = 1). To our knowledge, it is the first report that MCE is controlled by various clusters as nodes in MOFs.

To investigate the thermal stabilities and further confirm the free water molecules, thermogravimetric analysis were conducted on compounds 1–4, 1a, 4a, and 4b, shown in Figure S8, SI. Both of them display good thermal stability. For compound 1 and 1a, the weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C is 10.63% for 1 and 11.02% for 1a, corresponding to the loss of three coordinated and two free water molecules, being identical with the calculated: 10.82% for 1 and 10.69% for 1a. For compound 2, the weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C is 6.25%, corresponding to the loss of four coordinated and two free water molecules, being identical with the calculated: 6.41%. For compound 3, the weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C is 9.06%, corresponding to the loss of three coordinated and six free water molecules, being identical with the calculated: 8.69%. For compounds 4, 4a, and 4b, the weight loss from room temperature to 200 °C is 17.55% for 4, 17.53% for 4a, 16.62% for 4b, corresponding to the loss of coordinated and free water molecules, being identical with the calculated: 17.29% for 4, 17.26% for 4a, 16.64% for 4b. Obviously, compounds 3, 4, 4a, and 4b are still stable at 350 °C, which display higher thermal stability than compounds 1, 2, and 1a. As mentioned in the introduction, such result confirms MOFs based on clusters as nodes usually present excellent thermal stability.

Conclusions

In summary, seven 3D MOFs containing various [Gdn] as nodes were synthesized and magnetically characterized. All of them present excellent chemical and thermal stabilities. Noteworthily, structures and MCE investigations on them were controlled elaborately by controlling pH, temperature, and solvent. The [Gdn] nodes display endless variety and change, and the −ΔS m changes from 19.4 to 46.0 J·kg–1·K–1. The results confirm that high-spin the ground state of Mn2+ and Gd3+ are favorable to achieve high MCE, and the effect of magnetic density on MCE plays a dominant role for Gd3+-based compounds.
